question.questionText: When Amy added water to a mixture of baking soda and citric acid, the mixture began fizzing. Amy concluded there was a chemical reaction because it fizzed. Why is fizzing evidence of a chemical reaction?

referenceAnswers.referenceAnswer: The fizzing indicates a gas, a new material, is produced. When a new material is produced, a chemical reaction has occurred.

studentAnswers.studentAnswer: Because when it fizzing it releases a gas. When a gas forms from 2 materials it is a gas.
Because the baking soda and citric acid started out plain but when you poured water in it reacted.
Because it shows and once you see it you will know that it is a chemical reaction because it starts to look like little bubbles and that is what a chemical reaction is.

It created a gas and new material was made.
Because the 2 solutes and the solvent made a gas.
It indicates a gas.
Because the bubble makes the solution or mixture different.
Because it was letting out gas.
Gas was in it so that why it start fizzing.
It is a clue because it is making a gas and that is a clue so you know that a chemical reaction is about to happen.
Because you made a gas.
Because a chemical reaction creates gas bubbles or a precipitate.

Because it shows that something other than just doing nothing.
Because something has to happen for the precipitate to be made.
Because fizzing is created by gas bubbles.
Because fizzing is a sign of gas leaving a material and that is a chemical reaction.
